Charles Clover visited the island in October to meet the Ascension Island Government and the islanders. His visit was designed to coincide with a major expedition some of BLUE’s donors funded in the nick of time to look at the unexplored deep-water habitats around Ascension. Until this autumn, no one had looked at the island’s waters below dive depth. It was at the frontier of science. Twelve scientists from six top national institutes spent an intensive three days looking at what lived from 100 to 1000 metres from the British Antarctic Survey ship, the James Clark Ross. The results were both timely and persuasive, reminding the islanders of the uniqueness of what lies around their shores and tipping the scales further towards protection. Unprompted, the scientists called their report: ‘Marine biodiversity of Ascension Island’s shelf; scientific support for a marine protected area.’

The Vellmari team have trailed planting experiments of 300 seedlings on rocky substrate to cover rocky areas where the Posidonia oceanica meadows have been degraded, and results will be reviewed in April. A positive outcome would mark a significant achievement, marking the first successful restoration of its kind.

Our local partners, Vellmari, have conducted three boat trips to monitor Posidonia's flowering (sexual reproduction) in 2024, performing transects of 10 meters over Posidonia meadows at various depths and locations. For each transect, they made 10 measurements (one per meter) using 50x50 cm quadrats to count the number of flowers within this area. Unfortunately, no flowers were found during these outings, indicating a sparse flowering density for 2024, but this will not impact our restoration efforts. 
Instead, this data has informed our planting strategy for the year, with a focus towards using seedlings and plant fragments for restoration. This remains an effective method in enhancing meadow resilience and expansion, especially in areas impacted by storms or anchoring. The team will also conduct further monitoring in the coming months to check for any changes in the plant's flowering state.

The Government announced that Remote Electronic Monitoring (REM) (in other words cameras on boats) has been installed on the first vessel in the rollout of REM, following blue marine input.

The Government changed their original proposals for the rollout of Remote Electronic Monitoring (REM) to become more timely and ambitious, following blue marine input into the consultation, NGO collaboration and conversations with officials and parliamentarians quite strongly. Quote from government response to REM consultation: 'We do plan to proceed with some of our proposals but others have changed as a result of the feedback received from the consultation'.

The original proposal was that two vessels would have mandatory REM by 2028. Following a strong push to make this proposal a lot more ambitious and faster, the current proposal now states that: 
'Remote electronic monitoring systems will begin to be implemented in all priority fisheries within the next five years. This will apply to all vessels over 10m in length active within those fisheries in English waters, including non-UK vessels. Once we are satisfied that implementation issues have been resolved for each priority fishery, we will then make it mandatory to have these systems installed. There will be two years notice given of that to allow vessels time to adapt and for installation to take place.'

The first priority fishery has already begun this implementation process and will have REM installed at a time well before the original consultation was proposing. Our input helped apply pressure and move the needle on this.
